content.description: The graph shows the cost and revenue curves for a profit-maximizing monopolist that produces teddy bears. The letters in the graph represent the enclosed areas.
content.question: If the monopolist charges a single price for teddy bears, which of the following describes an accurate outcome?

choices.label: The consumer surplus equals area <math alttext="(a)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>a</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>, the producer surplus equals area <math alttext="(c)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>c</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>, and the deadweight loss equals area <math alttext="(b plus d, plus e)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>b</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>d</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>e</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>.

The consumer surplus equals area <math alttext="(b)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>b</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>, the producer surplus equals area <math alttext="(c plus d)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>c</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>d</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>, and the deadweight loss equals area <math alttext="(d plus e)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>d</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>e</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>.

The consumer surplus equals area <math alttext="(a, plus b)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>a</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>b</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>, the producer surplus equals area <math alttext="(c)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>c</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>, and the deadweight loss equals area <math alttext="(e plus f)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>e</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>f</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>.

Consumer surplus equals area <math alttext="(a, plus b)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>a</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>b</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>, producer surplus equals area <math alttext="(c plus d)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>c</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>d</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>, and deadweight loss equals area <math alttext="(e)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>e</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>.

The consumer surplus equals area <math alttext="(a)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>a</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>, the producer surplus equals area <math alttext="(c plus f)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>c</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>f</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>, and the deadweight loss equals area <math alttext="(b plus d, plus e)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>b</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>d</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>e</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>.

content.answer: Consumer surplus equals area <math alttext="(a, plus b)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>a</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>b</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>, producer surplus equals area <math alttext="(c plus d)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>c</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>d</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>, and deadweight loss equals area <math alttext="(e)" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>e</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>.

skill.text: Skill 3.A: Determine the outcome of an economic situation using economic concepts, principles, or models.
